image.altText: Two men wearing Tshirts with POLICE in yellow writing sit on the back of a boat out on the water

props.synopsis: At its closest point, Papua New Guinea is just 4 kilometres from Australia's islands in the Torres Strait, and local authorities warn this tropical archipelago has become an attractive route for drug smugglers.

title.children: Meth arrives in Australia from all over the world, but this route is destroying lives in PNG

image.altText: A man with a digitally blurred face talk to three people wearing Australian Border Force uniforms.

props.synopsis: A group of nearly 40 foreign nationals who arrived by boat to a remote part of WA on Friday are apparently headed to an offshore detention centre in Nauru, as the political fallout continues.

title.children: Suspected asylum seekers taken to Nauru as political storm over boat arrivals intensifies

image.altText: An artistic drawing of a large military ship floating on water with a little cloudy sky

props.synopsis: South Australia's defence sector, particularly shipbuilding, has been repeatedly spruiked as an economic boon and a pathway to long term prosperity, particularly in the wake of the demise of the automotive industry — but will what was promised actually be delivered?

title.children: Promises, plans and delays: A short history of major naval shipbuilding programs

image.altText: A man stands in front of a room

props.synopsis: Jason Farnsworth fell into a serious heroin addiction at 18 after his 16-month-old daughter Faith drowned. He managed to beat his addiction and went on to found several drug and alcohol support groups across regional South Australia.

title.children: People said he 'didn't stand a chance', but Jason, a heroin addict in Melbourne's underworld, turned his life around

image.altText: China's Qinling base

props.synopsis: When China opened its fifth research station in Antarctica this month, analysts sounded alarm bells about potential security threats on Australia's southern doorstep.

title.children: Security concerns grow as China opens its fifth base in Antarctica

image.altText: A man and male child sit on a couch reading a book together, you can't see their faces but the child is pointing at the pictures

props.synopsis: While there's no substitute for a qualified teacher, we've asked experts for their best tips for parents who want to help teach their kids to read at home.

title.children: Experts looked at 10,000 pieces of research to find the best way to learn to read – we've distilled it down for you

image.altText: A composite image of two men with neutral expressions

props.synopsis: Of all Vladimir Putin's critics, Alexei Navalny was probably the most fearless. It's one of the reasons he was so dangerous for the Russian president.

title.children: Navalny had a choice to stay a free man. This is why he decided to return to Russia

image.altText: A woman hugging a man from behind

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US, these South Asian women share what being in an interracial relationship has cost them.

title.children: 'Out of bounds': Women explain the complications of interracial relationships

image.altText: an outside shot of St Luke’s Catholic College at Marsden Park in Sydney which has tested positive for asbestos

props.synopsis: St Luke's Catholic College in Marsden Park and Penrith Christian School in Orchard Hills join the growing list of sites found to contain contaminated mulch.

title.children: Two more Sydney schools test positive for asbestos, one closes for week to clean up '30 cubic metres' of mulch

image.altText: A man holds two ventriloquist dummies overlaid on a composite of old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: In 1937, one of the most popular names in American radio stood just 90 centimetres tall and was made of wood and plastic — meet Charlie McCarthy and his puppeteer, Edgar Bergen.

title.children: Famous ventriloquist left his daughter nothing when he died — he bequeathed his puppet a fortune

image.altText: Angela Webster smiles at the camera in front of a box of fruit and veggies which she gets as part of a Sydney food co-op

props.synopsis: As the weekly grocery shop becomes increasingly more expensive for households, a dozen families are keeping a decades-old tradition alive in Sydney's inner west to get their fresh produce for the week.

title.children: Sydney families pool their money to buy groceries in bulk — it's saving them hundreds of dollars

image.altText: Taylor Swift against the backdrop of herself on screen

props.synopsis: Many of Taylor Swift's fans are over 45. What is it about her lovelorn ballads, kitchen bops and revenge anthems that appeal to middle-aged people?

title.children: 'It hit me exactly where I needed to be': How middle-aged fans fell for Taylor Swift

image.altText: A Nauru Airlines plane on the tarmac at Broome Airport, viewed through a cyclone fence with a staircase attached,

props.synopsis: Another group of foreign nationals turn up in Western Australia's remote north, following the discovery of about two dozen men near the tiny Indigenous community of Beagle Bay on Friday morning.

title.children: New group of suspected asylum seekers found in WA's north, taking total number to more than 35

image.altText: The thermodynamic god

props.synopsis: You've heard the arguments to put the brakes on the development of powerful Artificial Intelligence. But this secretive tech movement wants to do exactly the opposite.

title.children: Memes tell the story of a secret war in tech. It's no joke

image.altText: Composite of Harrison Ford as Han Solo holding a gun, and a printed movie script.

props.synopsis: The actor was said to have formed a genuine friendship with his landlords, leaving behind scripts, schedules and letters from his time filming Star Wars.

title.children: Original draft of Star Wars script left in London apartment by Harrison Ford fetches $20,821 at auction

image.altText: A frog with a brightly-coloured underbelly.

props.synopsis: A major university research project into critical peatland ecosystems in Western Australia has been given $1.4 million by a philanthropic organisation.

title.children: Research project focused on crucial ecosystem gets $1.4m boost

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: I know exactly your type — you love a weekend quiz and are convinced you'd outperform contestants on my show. Well, prove it.

title.children: Think you're a trivia guru? Let's see about that

image.altText: Musical medicals 2

props.synopsis: A group of Gold Coast medical students are performing as string quartet in an oncology ward to bring joy to people going through the darkest of times.

title.children: The medical students helping cancer patients one note at a time

image.altText: The burntout shells of a ute and a sedan on a scorched property,

props.synopsis: Victoria's Premier Jacinta Allan has confirmed one more home was destroyed by a bushfire at Pomonal. Meanwhile, more homes are being reconnected to power after last week's storm.

title.children: One further home confirmed destroyed in bushfires in Victoria's west, power restored to more properties

image.altText: A man sitting on a stage wearing a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Professor Ross Garnaut says Australia's economy experienced a "lost decade" from 2013 to 2023. Can these ideas turn things around, asks Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Can these economists turn things around for Australia's betrayed generations?

image.altText: the Dawwas family arrive in Sydney from Gaza 160224

props.synopsis: It's getting increasingly difficult for families leaving Gaza en route to Australia as they are forced to make the long trek without consular assistance.

title.children: The Dawwas family lost everything fleeing Gaza, including their father, and leaving is getting harder

image.altText: a family of five hugging on the beach

props.synopsis: A new study argues feminist language is being co-opted to sell health interventions that aren't backed up by evidence — like the anti-Müllerian hormone "egg timer" test.

title.children: Carla was told menopause was 'around the corner' and she didn't need birth control — all based on a hormone test

image.altText: A jetty reaches towards the horizon with a spectacular golden sunset behind it.

props.synopsis: The scrapped Cashless Debit Card has left a divisive legacy in the South Australian coastal town of Ceduna, which is facing a rise in crime and antisocial behaviour.

title.children: Ceduna is the jewel of the Nullarbor but residents fear crime is tarnishing its reputation

image.altText: A brown snake caught in a web by a redback spider

props.synopsis: They may be one of Australia's most deadly animals but Peter Marchal says it is not the first time he has seen a redback spider triumph against an eastern brown snake.

title.children: Redback spider catches baby eastern brown snake in its web

image.altText: Man in suit wearing thick rimmed glasses holds up fist.

props.synopsis: In 1974, two French doctors were called to the Iranian capital, Tehran. The doctors — specialists in blood diseases — had been asked to assess a government minister with cancer, but the appointment was odd.

title.children: When the Shah of Iran was diagnosed with cancer a revolution was already underway

image.altText: Ambika, left, sits in a grassy park with Leo laying down next to her, right. Both grin.

props.synopsis: Here's what's new to streaming and actually good in February, from the two surprisingly great remakes One Day and Mr and Mrs Smith, to the workplace satire that will make you lol.

title.children: Prepare to get your heart broken by David Nicholls's One Day all over again

image.altText: Simona Halep speaks to a crowd of media outside the Court of Arbitration for Sport

props.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Simona Halep sues the Canadian company that produced a nutritional supplement she believes led to her being handed a potentially career-ending four-year doping ban.

title.children: Halep sues supplements company she claims caused doping ban

image.altText: A dark-haired woman sits i9n a hardware store, reading a book.

props.synopsis: Discussing bathroom fittings and plastic piping is a far cry from the romantic tales this author writes about in her downtime.

title.children: When Frances isn't running her hardware store, she's writing romance novels

image.altText: Dom Young is on his haunches on the ground as teammates attend to him

props.synopsis: Dom Young says he is "all good" after a crusher tackle sent him to hospital in the Sydney Roosters' NRL pre-season defeat of Manly.

title.children: Young 'all good' after neck injury scare, Sipley to miss Vegas after crusher tackle

image.altText: a group of people wearing protective clothing in the cattleyards

props.synopsis: The government recently committed $43 million towards technology, staff training, better testing labs and other measures, including a former COVID-19 ambulance converted into a mobile field laboratory.

title.children: Victorian government on front foot with mock response to livestock disease that could cost country $80 billion

image.altText: An elderly man wears green face mask in car as photographers outside use flash cameras

props.synopsis: The 74-year-old, twice elected premier and ousted in a 2006 military coup, was given his freedom before sunrise on Sunday by King Maha Vajiralongkorn because of his age and health, after being treated at Bangkok's Police General Hospital.

title.children: Former Thailand prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra released from prison six months after return from exile

image.altText: A split image of a faded ace of diamonds with signatures on it, and windmill and water trough on dry country land.

props.synopsis: Found in the remote reaches of Western Australia's Gascoyne, Quobba Station is one of the largest of its kind in state. It change hands during a game of cards in the 1930s, according to local folklore — but not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Was this vast outback sheep station really won with a 650,000-to-one poker hand?

image.altText: Sue Kole in her backyard hugging her dog

props.synopsis: Plans to build a co-located private hospital at the Launceston General Hospital have been shelved just months before construction was due to start — with fears that will make Tasmania's growing waiting lists worse.

title.children: Sue's long wait for breast reconstruction surgery will get longer as hospital plans are dumped

image.altText: a lady in a yellow shirt feeding a cow a biscuit out of her mouth

props.synopsis: Health professionals are calling for national guidelines to be established in the animal-assisted therapy sector to ensure the safety and welfare of both participants and animals as demand for the service continues to grow.

title.children: As more people 'slow down' through animal-assisted therapy, some professionals say there needs to be regulation
